metadata.notes: Pillar 6 complete with boundary clarifications applied for QI science vs operational QI overlap with Pillar 3.

pillar.title: Education, Research, Knowledge and Innovation
pillar.definition: Training methods, CE, teaching, guidelines, evidence-based practice, clinical research, quality improvement, technology development, AI in anesthesia, theoretical or scientific exploration (including consciousness). This pillar encompasses how anesthesia knowledge is created, evaluated, transmitted, and advanced.
inclusion_tests: Is this about creating, evaluating, or transmitting knowledge?
Is this about how anesthesia professionals are trained or educated?
Is this about research methodology, evidence synthesis, or guideline development?
Is this about innovation pipelines (new drugs, devices, AI, digital health)?
Is this about quality improvement science (QI methods, PDSA, registries)?
Is this about scientific communication (publishing, conferences, dissemination)?
exclusion_tests: Clinical practice, physiology, patient care decisions → Pillar 1
Role definitions, scope boundaries, training requirements (who the provider IS) → Pillar 2
Systems, equipment, OR operations, IT infrastructure → Pillar 3
Legal requirements, compliance, malpractice, ethics statutes → Pillar 4
Compensation mechanics, billing, contracts, business structures → Pillar 5
Career paths, workforce deployment, job transitions, leadership roles → Pillar 7
Burnout, wellbeing, culture, OR politics, professional identity as lived experience → Pillar 8

sub_pillars.title: Education Systems, Programs and Pedagogy
sub_pillars.definition: The architecture, governance, and instructional methods of anesthesia training. This sub-pillar covers program structures (CRNA and physician), accreditation standards, curriculum design, teaching methodologies, adult learning principles, simulation-based education, and the integration of didactic and clinical experiences that produce competent anesthesia providers.

branches.title: Program Architecture, Governance and Accreditation
branches.definition: The structural components of anesthesia training programs including program types (CRNA, physician), duration, degree requirements, governance bodies, accreditation standards (COA, ACGME), and the organizations that oversee educational quality.
branches.lens: Understanding how anesthesia training programs are structured and regulated

topic_domains.title: CRNA Program Structures and Degree Requirements
topic_domains.definition: The architecture of nurse anesthesia education programs including Master's and DNP pathways, program duration (typically 3-4 years), credit requirements, and the evolution toward doctoral-level entry. Covers how programs balance didactic and clinical hours to meet professional standards.

topic_domains.title: Physician Anesthesiology Residency Architecture
topic_domains.definition: The structure of anesthesiology residency training including the 4-year program model, intern year integration, fellowship pathways, and progressive responsibility frameworks. Covers how residencies organize rotations and build toward independent practice.

topic_domains.title: COA Accreditation Standards and Processes
topic_domains.definition: The Council on Accreditation's requirements for CRNA programs including standards for curriculum, faculty qualifications, clinical experiences, and outcomes. Covers the accreditation cycle, self-study processes, site visits, and maintaining accredited status.

topic_domains.title: ACGME Program Requirements and Compliance
topic_domains.definition: The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education standards governing anesthesiology residencies. Covers program requirements, milestone reporting, Clinical Competency Committee functions, and annual program evaluation requirements.

topic_domains.title: Program Governance and Administrative Structures
topic_domains.definition: How anesthesia training programs are organized and led, including program director roles, curriculum committees, clinical coordinators, and relationships with parent institutions. Covers faculty requirements, governance models, and administrative best practices.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Site Networks and Affiliation Management
topic_domains.definition: The development and management of clinical training sites including affiliate hospitals, ambulatory surgery centers, and specialty rotations. Covers affiliation agreements, preceptor credentialing, site evaluation, and ensuring adequate case volume and diversity.

branches.title: Curriculum Design and Integration
branches.definition: How anesthesia curricula are developed, organized, and delivered. Includes didactic-clinical integration, rotation structures, spiral curricula, competency mapping, and the alignment of learning objectives with professional practice requirements.
branches.lens: Designing effective learning experiences across the training continuum

topic_domains.title: Curriculum Development Frameworks
topic_domains.definition: Systematic approaches to designing anesthesia curricula including Kern's six-step model, ADDIE (Analysis, Design, Development, Implementation, Evaluation), and backward design principles. Covers needs assessment, objective writing, and alignment with professional competencies.

topic_domains.title: Didactic-Clinical Integration Models
topic_domains.definition: Strategies for connecting classroom learning with clinical experiences including concurrent models, block scheduling, spiral curricula, and integrated case-based approaches. Covers timing, sequencing, and reinforcement of concepts across learning environments.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Rotation Design and Sequencing
topic_domains.definition: The structure and progression of clinical rotations including core rotations (general OR, OB, cardiac, pediatrics, ICU), electives, and specialty experiences. Covers rotation length, learning objectives, case mix requirements, and progressive autonomy.

topic_domains.title: Learning Objectives and Competency Mapping
topic_domains.definition: The process of defining what learners must know and do, and mapping these objectives to curriculum content, teaching methods, and assessments. Covers Bloom's taxonomy, competency frameworks, and ensuring curriculum covers all required domains.

topic_domains.title: Curriculum Evaluation and Continuous Improvement
topic_domains.definition: Methods for assessing curriculum effectiveness including graduate outcomes, board pass rates, employer feedback, and learner evaluations. Covers program evaluation models, data-driven curriculum revision, and continuous quality improvement cycles.

branches.title: Teaching Methods and Instructional Design
branches.definition: Pedagogical approaches for anesthesia education including adult learning theory (andragogy), competency-based education, flipped classrooms, case-based and team-based learning, clinical teaching techniques, feedback models, and remediation strategies.

topic_domains.title: Adult Learning Theory in Anesthesia Education
topic_domains.definition: Application of andragogy principles to anesthesia training, recognizing that adult learners are self-directed, bring experience, and need relevance. Covers Knowles' assumptions, experiential learning (Kolb), and designing instruction for adult clinicians.

topic_domains.title: Competency-Based Medical Education Principles
topic_domains.definition: The shift from time-based to competency-based progression, where learners advance by demonstrating mastery rather than completing rotations. Covers CBME frameworks, individualized learning paths, and implications for program structure.

topic_domains.title: Active Learning Formats and Instructional Strategies
topic_domains.definition: Teaching methods beyond traditional lecture including flipped classrooms, case-based learning, team-based learning, problem-based learning, and blended/hybrid approaches. Covers evidence for each method and implementation strategies.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Teaching and Preceptorship
topic_domains.definition: The art and science of teaching in clinical environments including bedside teaching techniques, cognitive apprenticeship, modeling expert thinking, and balancing education with patient care. Covers preceptor development and faculty training.

topic_domains.title: Feedback Models and Coaching Techniques
topic_domains.definition: Structured approaches to giving effective feedback including Pendleton's rules, ask-tell-ask, R2C2, and coaching frameworks. Covers formative feedback, debriefing conversations, and creating a growth-oriented learning climate.

topic_domains.title: Cognitive Load Management in Procedural Teaching
topic_domains.definition: Application of Cognitive Load Theory to teaching complex anesthesia skills, including strategies to reduce extraneous load, manage intrinsic complexity, and build schemas. Covers task decomposition, scaffolding, and deliberate practice design.

topic_domains.title: Remediation Strategies and Learner Support
topic_domains.definition: Approaches for supporting struggling learners including early identification, diagnostic assessment, individualized learning plans, and structured remediation programs. Covers due process, documentation, and decision-making for advancement.

branches.title: Simulation and Experiential Learning
branches.definition: The use of simulation across the fidelity spectrum—from task trainers to high-fidelity mannequins to virtual reality—for skills acquisition, crisis management, and team training. Includes simulation center operations, scenario design, debriefing methods, and in-situ simulation.

topic_domains.title: Simulation Modalities and Fidelity Spectrum
topic_domains.definition: The range of simulation technologies from low-fidelity task trainers to high-fidelity mannequins, screen-based simulators, and virtual/augmented reality. Covers selecting appropriate fidelity for learning objectives and resource constraints.

topic_domains.title: Simulation Center Design and Operations
topic_domains.definition: The infrastructure, staffing, and operational elements of running an anesthesia simulation program. Covers space design, equipment acquisition, scheduling, faculty development, and program sustainability.

topic_domains.title: Scenario Design and Development
topic_domains.definition: The process of creating effective simulation scenarios including learning objective alignment, case scripting, confederate roles, embedded triggers, and scenario testing. Covers templates, scenario libraries, and interprofessional scenario design.

topic_domains.title: Debriefing Methods and Facilitation
topic_domains.definition: Structured approaches to post-simulation reflection including Plus-Delta, PEARLS (Promoting Excellence and Reflective Learning), advocacy-inquiry, and the Debriefing with Good Judgment model. Covers facilitator training and debriefing assessment tools (DASH).

topic_domains.title: Crisis Resource Management Training
topic_domains.definition: Simulation-based training in non-technical skills essential for managing anesthesia emergencies including teamwork, communication, situational awareness, leadership, and decision-making under pressure. Covers CRM history, principles, and curriculum design.

topic_domains.title: In-Situ Simulation and Systems Testing
topic_domains.definition: Conducting simulations in actual clinical environments (OR, ICU) with real staff to identify latent safety threats and improve team performance. Covers logistics, psychological safety, just-in-time training, and using simulation for systems improvement.

sub_pillars.title: Assessment, Competency and Lifelong Learning
sub_pillars.definition: How anesthesia professionals are evaluated, credentialed, and maintained throughout their careers. This sub-pillar covers competency frameworks, workplace-based assessment, certification exams, continuing education requirements, self-assessment, and the systems that ensure providers remain current from initial training through retirement.

branches.title: Knowledge and Clinical Skills Assessment
branches.definition: Methods for evaluating cognitive knowledge and procedural skills including written examinations, OSCEs, oral boards, procedural checklists, and skills sign-offs. Covers exam design, psychometric principles, and standard-setting methods.
branches.lens: Measuring what learners know and can do

topic_domains.title: Written Examination Design and Psychometrics
topic_domains.definition: The science of constructing valid and reliable written tests including multiple-choice item writing, blueprint development, item analysis, and psychometric properties. Covers test construction principles, item response theory basics, and quality assurance in exam development.

topic_domains.title: OSCE Design and Implementation
topic_domains.definition: Creating and running Objective Structured Clinical Examinations for anesthesia competencies. Covers station design, standardized patient training, checklist vs global rating scales, logistics, and ensuring validity and reliability across stations.

topic_domains.title: Oral Examination Methods
topic_domains.definition: The design and conduct of oral/viva examinations including structured oral exams, case-based questioning, and the oral board format used by ABA. Covers examiner training, standardization, scoring rubrics, and managing examiner variability.

topic_domains.title: Procedural Skills Assessment
topic_domains.definition: Methods for evaluating technical competence in anesthesia procedures including direct observation checklists, video review, procedure logs, and simulation-based skills testing. Covers defining procedural competence thresholds and sign-off processes.

topic_domains.title: Standard-Setting Methods
topic_domains.definition: Techniques for establishing pass/fail cut scores including Modified Angoff, Hofstee, borderline group, and contrasting groups methods. Covers selecting appropriate methods, conducting standard-setting panels, and defending defensible cut scores.

topic_domains.title: In-Training Examination Programs
topic_domains.definition: The design and use of annual knowledge assessments during training including ACGME ITEs and program-specific exams. Covers benchmarking, identifying at-risk trainees, longitudinal tracking, and using results for curriculum improvement.

branches.title: Workplace-Based Assessment and Feedback
branches.definition: Assessment conducted during real clinical practice including direct observation (Mini-CEX, DOPS), case logs, 360° feedback, and structured feedback delivery. Covers rater training, bias mitigation, and formative assessment practices.
branches.lens: Evaluating performance in authentic clinical settings

topic_domains.title: Direct Observation Assessment Tools
topic_domains.definition: Structured instruments for evaluating trainees during clinical care including Mini-CEX (Mini-Clinical Evaluation Exercise), DOPS (Direct Observation of Procedural Skills), and case-based discussions. Covers tool selection, implementation, and aggregating observations.

topic_domains.title: Case Logs and Procedure Tracking Systems
topic_domains.definition: Documentation systems for recording clinical experiences including case numbers, procedure types, and complexity. Covers minimum case requirements, electronic logging systems, and using case data for competency decisions.

topic_domains.title: Multi-Source Feedback Systems
topic_domains.definition: Collecting performance data from multiple perspectives including peers, nurses, surgeons, patients, and self-assessment (360° feedback). Covers survey design, anonymity, aggregation, and using MSF for interpersonal and communication competencies.

topic_domains.title: Rater Training and Bias Mitigation
topic_domains.definition: Strategies for improving assessment quality by training evaluators and reducing systematic biases. Covers frame-of-reference training, calibration exercises, implicit bias awareness, and using multiple raters to improve reliability.

topic_domains.title: Portfolio-Based Assessment
topic_domains.definition: Using curated collections of learner work products, reflections, and evidence for holistic evaluation. Covers portfolio design, required elements, review processes, and integrating portfolios into competency decisions.

branches.title: Competency Frameworks, Milestones and EPAs
branches.definition: The conceptual structures defining what anesthesia professionals must be able to do. Includes ACGME Milestones, Entrustable Professional Activities, competency committees, progression decisions, and holistic trainee evaluation.

topic_domains.title: ACGME Core Competencies in Anesthesiology
topic_domains.definition: The six ACGME competency domains (Patient Care, Medical Knowledge, Practice-Based Learning, Interpersonal Skills, Professionalism, Systems-Based Practice) and their application to anesthesiology training. Covers definitions, sub-competencies, and integration into curricula.

topic_domains.title: Anesthesiology Milestones and Developmental Progression
topic_domains.definition: The ACGME Milestones framework defining expected developmental trajectories across competency domains. Covers milestone levels, narrative descriptors, semi-annual reporting, and using milestones to track trainee progression.

topic_domains.title: Entrustable Professional Activities in Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Defining the core clinical activities that trainees must be trusted to perform unsupervised. Covers EPA development, entrustment scales, mapping EPAs to competencies, and making entrustment decisions.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Competency Committee Operations
topic_domains.definition: The structure and function of committees that synthesize assessment data and make trainee progression decisions. Covers committee composition, meeting processes, data presentation, group decision-making, and documentation.

topic_domains.title: Promotion, Remediation and Dismissal Decisions
topic_domains.definition: The high-stakes decisions about trainee advancement including criteria for promotion, identifying struggling learners, remediation processes, probation, and dismissal. Covers due process, documentation, and legal considerations.

branches.title: Certification, Recertification and Continuing Education
branches.definition: The systems ensuring initial and ongoing competence of practicing providers. Includes NBCRNA/ABA certification, maintenance of certification (MOCA, CPC), CME/CE requirements, self-assessment modules, and lifelong learning frameworks.

topic_domains.title: NBCRNA Certification and Continued Professional Certification
topic_domains.definition: The National Board of Certification and Recertification for Nurse Anesthetists certification process including initial exam, CPC program requirements, Class A and B credits, core modules, and the certification cycle. Covers maintaining active certification status.

topic_domains.title: ABA Certification and MOCA Requirements
topic_domains.definition: The American Board of Anesthesiology initial certification pathway and Maintenance of Certification in Anesthesiology (MOCA) program. Covers exam components, MOCA parts (CME, self-assessment, QI), and continuous certification requirements.

topic_domains.title: CME/CE Accreditation and Credit Systems
topic_domains.definition: The structure of continuing medical education including ACCME accreditation, AMA PRA Category 1 credits, state requirements, and specialty-specific CE. Covers how CME is developed, approved, and documented.

topic_domains.title: Self-Directed and Just-in-Time Learning
topic_domains.definition: Approaches to learning driven by individual needs and immediate clinical questions. Covers self-assessment to identify gaps, point-of-care resources (UpToDate, apps), and integrating just-in-time learning into practice.

topic_domains.title: Digital Learning Platforms and Microlearning
topic_domains.definition: Modern delivery formats for continuing education including online modules, mobile apps, podcasts, spaced repetition tools, and bite-sized learning units. Covers platform selection, engagement strategies, and evidence for digital CE effectiveness.

topic_domains.title: Quality Improvement as Continuing Education
topic_domains.definition: Using participation in QI projects to fulfill CE requirements (MOCA Part 4, NBCRNA requirements). Covers structuring QI for educational credit, documenting participation, and linking improvement work to professional development.

sub_pillars.title: Research, Evidence and Quality Science
sub_pillars.definition: The creation, synthesis, and application of knowledge to improve anesthesia practice. This sub-pillar covers research methodology (clinical trials, observational studies, qualitative research), evidence evaluation, guideline development, quality improvement science, registries, and the frameworks that translate evidence into practice change.

branches.title: Clinical Research Methodology
branches.definition: The design and conduct of research studies in anesthesia including randomized controlled trials, observational studies (cohort, case-control), qualitative methods, survey research, and the ethical/regulatory requirements (IRB, informed consent) governing human subjects research.
branches.lens: How to generate valid new knowledge

topic_domains.title: Randomized Controlled Trial Design
topic_domains.definition: The principles and practice of designing RCTs in anesthesia including randomization methods, blinding strategies, sample size calculation, control selection, and pragmatic vs explanatory trial designs. Covers CONSORT reporting standards and common design variations (crossover, cluster, adaptive).

topic_domains.title: Observational Study Designs
topic_domains.definition: Non-randomized research methods including cohort studies (prospective and retrospective), case-control studies, and cross-sectional designs. Covers appropriate applications, controlling for confounding, and STROBE reporting guidelines.

topic_domains.title: Qualitative and Mixed Methods Research
topic_domains.definition: Research approaches that explore experiences, behaviors, and perceptions through interviews, focus groups, and observation. Covers qualitative paradigms, data collection methods, thematic analysis, and integrating qualitative with quantitative methods.

topic_domains.title: Survey Research Methods
topic_domains.definition: Designing and conducting survey studies including questionnaire construction, sampling strategies, response optimization, and data analysis. Covers validity, reliability, and common pitfalls in survey research.

topic_domains.title: Research Ethics and IRB Navigation
topic_domains.definition: Ethical principles governing human subjects research including informed consent, vulnerable populations, risk-benefit analysis, and privacy protections. Covers IRB submission, approval categories, and maintaining ethical compliance throughout studies.

topic_domains.title: Research Funding and Grant Writing
topic_domains.definition: Securing resources for anesthesia research including identifying funding sources (NIH, IARS, ASA Foundation, AANA), understanding grant mechanisms (R01, K-series, foundation grants), and writing competitive applications.

branches.title: Data Systems, Registries and Analytics
branches.definition: The infrastructure for collecting and analyzing anesthesia data at scale. Includes national registries (NACOR, MPOG), institutional databases, big data approaches, machine learning applications in research, and the use of data for benchmarking and outcomes research.

topic_domains.title: National Anesthesia Registries: NACOR and MPOG
topic_domains.definition: The structure and use of major anesthesia data repositories including the National Anesthesia Clinical Outcomes Registry (NACOR) and Multicenter Perioperative Outcomes Group (MPOG). Covers data elements, participation, and research applications.

topic_domains.title: Institutional Data and EHR-Based Research
topic_domains.definition: Conducting research using electronic health records and institutional databases. Covers data extraction, common data models, linking datasets, and the opportunities and limitations of retrospective EHR research.

topic_domains.title: Big Data Analytics and Machine Learning in Research
topic_domains.definition: Applying computational methods to large anesthesia datasets including predictive modeling, pattern recognition, and algorithm development. Covers machine learning basics, model validation, and translating findings to clinical insight.

topic_domains.title: Biostatistics for Anesthesia Research
topic_domains.definition: Statistical methods commonly used in anesthesia research from descriptive statistics through multivariate regression, survival analysis, and propensity score methods. Covers selecting appropriate analyses and interpreting results.

topic_domains.title: Research Data Management and Reproducibility
topic_domains.definition: Best practices for handling research data including data collection, storage, cleaning, documentation, and sharing. Covers reproducibility principles, code sharing, data repositories, and meeting funder requirements for data management.

branches.title: Evidence Synthesis and Evaluation
branches.definition: Methods for appraising and combining existing research. Includes systematic review methodology, meta-analysis, network meta-analysis, evidence grading systems (GRADE, Oxford levels), and critical appraisal of literature quality.
branches.lens: Making sense of the existing evidence base

topic_domains.title: Systematic Review Methodology
topic_domains.definition: The rigorous process of identifying, selecting, and synthesizing all relevant research on a clinical question. Covers protocol development, search strategies, screening, data extraction, risk of bias assessment, and PRISMA reporting.

topic_domains.title: Meta-Analysis Techniques
topic_domains.definition: Statistical methods for combining results across studies including effect size calculation, fixed vs random effects models, heterogeneity assessment, and sensitivity analyses. Covers forest plots, funnel plots, and interpreting pooled results.

topic_domains.title: Network Meta-Analysis
topic_domains.definition: Advanced synthesis methods that compare multiple interventions simultaneously, even when not directly compared in trials. Covers network geometry, consistency assumptions, ranking treatments, and presenting network meta-analysis results.

topic_domains.title: Evidence Grading Systems
topic_domains.definition: Frameworks for rating the quality of evidence and strength of recommendations including GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) and Oxford Centre levels. Covers applying these systems and communicating certainty.

topic_domains.title: Critical Appraisal of Clinical Literature
topic_domains.definition: Skills for evaluating the validity, importance, and applicability of published research. Covers appraisal tools for different study designs, identifying bias, and determining whether findings should change practice.

branches.title: Guideline Development and Knowledge Translation
branches.definition: The process of converting evidence into actionable recommendations and implementing them in practice. Includes consensus methods (Delphi, Nominal Group), guideline writing, knowledge translation frameworks (KTA, PARiHS), implementation science, and de-implementation of low-value practices.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Practice Guideline Development
topic_domains.definition: The process of creating evidence-based recommendations including forming guideline panels, defining clinical questions (PICO), synthesizing evidence, and formulating recommendations. Covers ASA and AANA guideline processes and AGREE II quality standards.

topic_domains.title: Consensus Methods for Evidence Gaps
topic_domains.definition: Structured approaches to reaching expert agreement when evidence is lacking including Delphi technique, Nominal Group Technique, and consensus conferences. Covers when to use consensus, conducting panels, and reporting results.

topic_domains.title: Knowledge Translation Frameworks
topic_domains.definition: Theoretical models for moving research into practice including the Knowledge-to-Action (KTA) cycle, PARiHS (Promoting Action on Research Implementation in Health Services), and RE-AIM. Covers assessing context and planning implementation.

topic_domains.title: Implementation Science in Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: The study of methods to promote uptake of evidence-based practices into routine care. Covers implementation strategies, barrier and facilitator assessment, fidelity measurement, and sustainability of practice change.

topic_domains.title: De-Implementation of Low-Value Practices
topic_domains.definition: The science of reducing or stopping ineffective, unproven, or harmful practices. Covers identifying low-value care, overcoming inertia, Choosing Wisely initiatives, and strategies for successful de-implementation.

branches.title: Quality Improvement Science and Safety
branches.definition: The science of systematically improving healthcare processes and outcomes. Includes QI methodologies (PDSA, Lean, Six Sigma), measurement and analytics (run charts, SPC), human factors engineering, safety culture, high-reliability concepts, and QI collaboratives.

topic_domains.title: Model for Improvement and PDSA Cycles
topic_domains.definition: The foundational QI framework as a science and methodology: setting aims, selecting measures, and testing changes through iterative Plan-Do-Study-Act cycles. Covers the theoretical basis, teaching the model, research on improvement science, and scholarly approaches to QI. (Operational application to specific workflows → Pillar 3)

topic_domains.title: Lean Methodology in Perioperative Care
topic_domains.definition: Applying Lean principles to eliminate waste and improve flow in anesthesia and surgical services. Covers value stream mapping, identifying waste types (muda), rapid improvement events, and sustaining Lean culture.

topic_domains.title: Six Sigma and DMAIC in Healthcare
topic_domains.definition: Using Six Sigma methodology to reduce variation and defects in clinical processes. Covers the DMAIC cycle (Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control), statistical tools, and applying Six Sigma to anesthesia quality problems.

topic_domains.title: Statistical Process Control and Measurement
topic_domains.definition: Using run charts and control charts to distinguish true improvement from random variation. Covers constructing charts, identifying special cause variation, and using measurement to guide QI decisions.

topic_domains.title: Root Cause Analysis and Failure Mode Analysis
topic_domains.definition: The science and methodology of investigating adverse events (RCA) and proactively identifying potential failures (FMEA). Covers analytical frameworks, conducting rigorous analyses, identifying system factors, research on safety investigation methods, and teaching these techniques. (Operational incident investigation → Pillar 3)

topic_domains.title: Human Factors and Ergonomics in Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Applying human factors engineering to design safer anesthesia systems including equipment design, workspace layout, alarm management, and reducing error-prone conditions. Covers human factors principles and their application to patient safety.

topic_domains.title: Safety Culture and High Reliability
topic_domains.definition: Creating organizational cultures that prioritize safety including psychological safety, just culture, and High Reliability Organization (HRO) principles. Covers measuring safety culture, leadership behaviors, and sustaining a safety focus.

sub_pillars.title: Innovation and Knowledge Dissemination
sub_pillars.definition: The frontier of anesthesia science and how knowledge is shared. This sub-pillar covers medical device and drug development, artificial intelligence and machine learning, digital health technologies, emerging scientific frontiers (consciousness, pharmacogenomics), scholarly publishing, scientific communication, and the dissemination of knowledge through traditional and digital channels.

branches.title: Medical Device and Drug Development
branches.definition: The innovation pipeline for new anesthesia technologies and therapeutics. Includes R&D processes, regulatory pathways (FDA 510(k), PMA, IND/NDA), clinical trial phases, intellectual property, technology transfer, and commercialization.
branches.lens: Bringing new technologies from concept to bedside

topic_domains.title: Medical Device Innovation Pipeline
topic_domains.definition: The stages of bringing new anesthesia devices from concept to market including ideation, prototyping, bench testing, preclinical studies, and clinical validation. Covers the innovation process, common pathways, and timelines for device development.

topic_domains.title: FDA Regulatory Pathways for Medical Devices
topic_domains.definition: The regulatory framework governing anesthesia devices including 510(k) premarket notification, Premarket Approval (PMA), De Novo classification, and breakthrough device designation. Covers requirements, submission processes, and post-market surveillance.

topic_domains.title: Anesthetic Drug Development and Approval
topic_domains.definition: The pharmaceutical development pipeline for anesthetic agents including preclinical testing, IND applications, Phase I-III clinical trials, NDA submission, and post-marketing requirements. Covers the drug approval process and pharmacovigilance.

topic_domains.title: Intellectual Property and Patent Strategy
topic_domains.definition: Protecting innovations through patents, trade secrets, and other IP mechanisms. Covers patent basics, freedom-to-operate analysis, invention disclosure, and IP considerations for clinician-inventors.

topic_domains.title: Technology Transfer and Commercialization
topic_domains.definition: The process of moving innovations from academic or clinical settings to market. Covers working with technology transfer offices, licensing agreements, startup formation, and industry partnerships.

topic_domains.title: Innovation Ecosystems and Partnerships
topic_domains.definition: The networks and resources supporting anesthesia innovation including industry collaborations, incubators, accelerators, innovation grants (SBIR/STTR), and professional society innovation programs.

branches.title: Artificial Intelligence and Digital Health
branches.definition: Emerging computational and digital technologies in anesthesia. Includes machine learning and predictive analytics, clinical decision support, closed-loop systems, automation, telemedicine, mobile health apps, wearable sensors, and regulatory frameworks for AI-enabled devices.

topic_domains.title: Machine Learning Fundamentals for Clinicians
topic_domains.definition: Core concepts of artificial intelligence and machine learning relevant to anesthesia practitioners. Covers supervised vs unsupervised learning, model training and validation, common algorithms, and interpreting ML outputs without requiring programming expertise.

topic_domains.title: Predictive Analytics in Perioperative Care
topic_domains.definition: Applications of AI/ML to forecast clinical events such as hypotension, difficult airway, postoperative complications, and resource needs. Covers current tools, evidence for predictive models, and integrating predictions into clinical workflow.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Decision Support Systems
topic_domains.definition: AI-enabled tools that provide recommendations, alerts, or guidance during anesthesia care. Covers types of decision support, integration with anesthesia information systems, alert fatigue, and evaluating decision support effectiveness.

topic_domains.title: Closed-Loop Anesthesia Systems
topic_domains.definition: Automated systems that adjust anesthetic delivery based on physiological feedback (BIS, blood pressure, neuromuscular monitoring). Covers control algorithms, current closed-loop technologies, regulatory status, and the path toward autonomous anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Telemedicine and Tele-Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Remote delivery of anesthesia services including teleconsultation, remote supervision, and tele-ICU sedation management. Covers technology platforms, regulatory considerations, and models for extending anesthesiologist reach.

topic_domains.title: Wearables and Mobile Health in Perioperative Care
topic_domains.definition: Consumer and medical-grade wearable sensors and mobile applications for perioperative monitoring and patient engagement. Covers continuous monitoring, patient-generated data, and integrating mHealth into anesthesia practice.

branches.title: Emerging Scientific Frontiers
branches.definition: Novel areas of scientific inquiry relevant to anesthesia. Includes consciousness research, pharmacogenomics and precision medicine, chronobiology, neuroscience of anesthesia mechanisms, and translational science connecting basic research to clinical application.
branches.lens: The cutting edge of anesthesia science

topic_domains.title: Consciousness and Mechanisms of Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Neuroscience research exploring how anesthetics produce unconsciousness, amnesia, and immobility. Covers theories of consciousness (integrated information, global workspace), neural correlates, and implications for awareness monitoring.

topic_domains.title: Pharmacogenomics and Precision Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Using genetic information to individualize anesthetic selection and dosing. Covers pharmacogenomic variants affecting drug metabolism (CYP enzymes), opioid response, and the future of genetically-guided anesthesia care.

topic_domains.title: Chronobiology and Circadian Considerations
topic_domains.definition: The influence of biological rhythms on anesthesia and surgery including time-of-day effects on drug pharmacology, surgical outcomes, and recovery. Covers circadian science and implications for scheduling and drug timing.

topic_domains.title: Translational Science in Anesthesiology
topic_domains.definition: Bridging basic science discoveries to clinical application including bench-to-bedside research, reverse translation, and the translational research pipeline. Covers frameworks for moving fundamental findings toward patient benefit.

topic_domains.title: Neurotoxicity and Long-Term Anesthesia Effects
topic_domains.definition: Research on potential long-term effects of anesthesia exposure including developmental neurotoxicity in pediatric patients and postoperative cognitive dysfunction in elderly patients. Covers current evidence, ongoing research, and clinical implications.

branches.title: Scholarly Publishing and Peer Review
branches.definition: The formal systems for disseminating research findings. Includes peer review processes, journal publishing, open access models, preprint servers, authorship standards, publication ethics, reproducibility practices, and bibliometrics.
branches.lens: How research enters the scientific record

topic_domains.title: The Peer Review Process
topic_domains.definition: How scientific manuscripts are evaluated before publication including reviewer roles, review criteria, editorial decision-making, and responding to reviewer comments. Covers being an effective reviewer and navigating the review process as an author.

topic_domains.title: Manuscript Preparation and Journal Submission
topic_domains.definition: Writing and formatting research manuscripts for publication including structure (IMRAD), journal selection, cover letters, and submission systems. Covers strategies for successful publication and common rejection reasons.

topic_domains.title: Open Access and Publishing Models
topic_domains.definition: The landscape of scholarly publishing including traditional subscription journals, open access (gold, green, hybrid), preprint servers (medRxiv, bioRxiv), and article processing charges. Covers choosing publication venues and understanding access implications.

topic_domains.title: Authorship Standards and Publication Ethics
topic_domains.definition: Ethical principles governing scholarly communication including ICMJE authorship criteria, contributor roles, conflicts of interest disclosure, and avoiding misconduct (plagiarism, fabrication, duplicate publication). Covers COPE guidelines and responsible authorship.

topic_domains.title: Bibliometrics and Research Impact Measurement
topic_domains.definition: Quantitative measures of research influence including journal Impact Factor, citation counts, h-index, and alternative metrics. Covers understanding, using, and critiquing bibliometric indicators for career development.

branches.title: Scientific Communication and Public Engagement
branches.definition: How anesthesia knowledge reaches diverse audiences beyond peer-reviewed publication. Includes conference presentations, digital scholarship (FOAMed, podcasts, blogs), social media, science communication to lay audiences, and altmetrics.

topic_domains.title: Conference Presentations and Academic Speaking
topic_domains.definition: Skills for presenting research at scientific meetings including abstract submission, poster design, oral presentation techniques, and handling Q&A. Covers maximizing impact and visibility at professional conferences.

topic_domains.title: Digital Scholarship and FOAMed
topic_domains.definition: Engaging with Free Open Access Medical Education resources including blogs, podcasts, videos, and social media educational content. Covers consuming, creating, and evaluating FOAMed resources in anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Social Media for Professional Communication
topic_domains.definition: Using platforms (Twitter/X, LinkedIn, professional networks) to share research, build professional identity, and engage with the anesthesia community. Covers best practices, risks, and institutional policies.

topic_domains.title: Science Communication to Lay Audiences
topic_domains.definition: Translating anesthesia science for patients, media, and the general public. Covers plain language communication, media interviews, public lectures, and combating misinformation about anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Altmetrics and Online Research Impact
topic_domains.definition: Measuring the broader reach of research beyond citations including social media mentions, news coverage, policy documents, and public engagement. Covers altmetric tools, interpreting scores, and understanding online attention.
